docs.lead_paragraph: A pediatrician at Yale says he has developed an improved technique for detecting lice eggs, known as nits, raising hope for the day when parents will not have to spend long hours delousing their children -- only to find that a few missed eggs forces them to begin all over again. Dr. Sydney Z. Spiesel, an assistant professor at the Yale School of Medicine, has invented a shampoo that, after a single application, stains the lice and their nits so that when exposed to commonly available ultraviolet or black light sources, they glow brightly. The nits, the size and color of a grain of sand, can then be easily spotted and removed.

headline.main: A Shampoo That Highlights Head Lice

docs.abstract: Prof Sydney Z Spiesel has invented shampoo that stains head lice and their eggs, known as nits, so that they glow brightly when exposed to ultraviolet or black light sources and can be easily spotted and removed; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Smoking and heavy drinking are two risky behaviors that often go together. But when combined, it now seems, they play an increased role in causing a genetic mutation linked to lung cancer. Tobacco is known to produce changes in the tumor-suppressor gene p53, and to be the major cause of lung cancer. The tobacco-cancer link is so great that Dr. Steven A. Ahrendt of the Medical College of Wisconsin, whose research team sought lung-cancer patients for a new study, said, ''We had to get 140 just to get 10 nonsmokers.''

headline.main: Alcohol Heightens Risks of Tobacco Use

docs.abstract: Study led by Dr Steven A Ahrendt finds smoking and heavy drinking, when combined, play increased role in causing genetic mutation linked to lung cancer; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Several studies have found that medical diagnoses and treatments are often different depending on whether a patient is black or white. Now, researchers at Duke University believe that they have found evidence that the attitudes that affect the behavior of doctors can be seen in the earliest stages of a student's medical school experience.

headline.main: Medical Students' Biases Can Begin Early

docs.abstract: Duke University researchers find medical students display early in their training attitudes that can lead to medical diagnoses and treatments that differ with patient's race and gender (M)
docs.snippet: Several studies have found that medical diagnoses and treatments are often different depending on whether a patient is black or white.    Now, researchers at Duke University believe that they have found evidence that the attitudes that affect the...

docs.lead_paragraph: When women reach menopause, many struggle with the decision of whether to take hormone replacement therapy. It often comes down to weighing the compelling benefits against the disturbing drawbacks. The benefits are relief of symptoms like hot flashes and insomnia as well as a lowered risk of osteoporosis and of high cholesterol. (Until recently, many doctors believed that hormone replacement therapy also reduces risk of heart disease, but that finding has now been questioned.) The drawbacks, most notably, are an increased risk of blood clots and breast cancer.

headline.main: Natural Remedies for Menopause Gain Popularity

docs.abstract: Growing number of postmenopausal women are trying to sidestep decision on hormone replacement therapy by chosing 'natural' alternatives; these include food and herbal supplements containing plant estrogens, phytoestrogens, that have estrogen-like effects when taken by humans; also include creams made with hormone progesterone and cocktails made up of vitamins, minerals and herbs; experts say most natural remedies are probably safe at low doses; fear some women take unsafe doses; photo (M)
docs.snippet: When women reach menopause, many struggle with the decision of whether to take hormone replacement therapy. It often comes down to weighing the compelling benefits against the disturbing drawbacks.    The benefits are relief of symptoms like hot...

docs.lead_paragraph: To listen to the manufacturers of an ever-growing list of germ-fighting products -- including antibacterial soaps and sprays, toothbrushes and toothpastes, pajamas and slippers, sheets and mattresses, potty chairs, high chairs, toys, sponges, cutting boards and even chopsticks and paper towels -- my family and I should have been riddled with disease all these many years. My husband is allergic to antibacterial soaps, so we abandoned them 34 years ago. I do not have a dishwasher, so our dishes, glasses and utensils are not ''sterilized'' at high temperatures. I had no clothes dryer for 20 years and still don't use one for drying and ''sterilizing'' our clothes. We use sponges to wipe the kitchen counters and cloth towels to dry our hands. We ride the subways, often holding the poles that the ads tell us are crawling with billions of germs. And we do not use instant ''hand sanitizer.''

headline.main: How Germ-Phobia Can Lead to Illness

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column holds people frightened by microbial world may be adopting approach that actually fosters rather than suppresses serious infections; warns antibacterial products now crowding marketplace upset natural balance of microorganisms and spur evolution of bacteria resistant to both animicrobials and antibiotics; offers advice on proper hygiene; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Emergency angioplasty is a proven way to save the lives of patients having heart attacks, but two new studies suggest that for it to be most effective, time is of the essence. One report, by researchers at Brigham and Women's Hospital, found that for the best survival rate, the procedure should be done within two hours after a patient arrives at the hospital. The study looked at more than 27,000 heart attack patients treated at 661 hospitals from 1994 to 1998.
docs.abstract: Brigham and Women's Hospital researchers finds angioplasty survival rate is highest when procedure is done within two hours after heart attack patient arrives at hospital; another study, led by Dr John G Canto, confirms longstanding belief that patients given emergency angioplasties at hospitals that perform large numbers of procedures have lower mortality rates; finds failure of smaller hospitals to administer procedure quickly enough seems to play role (M)
docs.snippet: Emergency angioplasty is a proven way to save the lives of patients having heart attacks, but two new studies suggest that for it to be most effective, time is of the essence.    One report, by researchers at Brigham and Women's Hospital, found that...

docs.lead_paragraph: Diagnosing attention deficit hyperactivity disorder has never been easy. Doctors say that it frequently rests on nothing firmer than judgment calls on difficult questions like these: Does the kindergartner who cannot sit still and pay attention in class have the developmental disorder, or is he just immature?
docs.abstract: Dr Thomas E Brown, editor of new book in which researchers describe findings on causes and symptoms of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, says disorder is more complex than most people think; research underscores two points that are key to improving diagnosis and treatment: that people with disorder are at very high risk of having or developing various other problems and that many people with disorder seem to have chronic difficulty with brain's executive functions, including short-term memory, planning and staying focused on task; photos (M)
docs.snippet: Diagnosing attention deficit hyperactivity disorder has never been easy. Doctors say that it frequently rests on nothing firmer than judgment calls on difficult questions like these:    Does the kindergartner who cannot sit still and pay attention in...

docs.lead_paragraph: Young women dashing about, say, the lacrosse field and then swilling soda to celebrate victory seems like the kind of image commonly seen in television commercials. But a new study adds a jarring note to this scene. Those girls have a much higher chance of suffering a fractured bone, especially if their soda of choice is cola, Harvard researchers say.

headline.main: Cola Is No Boon for Bones, Study Says

docs.abstract: Study by Prof Grace Wyshak finds active girls who drink cola are five times as likely to fracture bones as are girls who do not drink any soda; photo (M)
